In pictures: Stokesley bungalow blaze damping down
Firefighters have released these pictures of a fire which swept through the roofs of four bungalows in North Yorkshire.
Fire crews are removing roof tiles and damping down after the fire spread through the four terraced properties.
Police say all the homes had to be evacuated and are asking people to avoid the area while emergency services work at the scene.
Two crews from Northallerton and engines from Stokesley, Middlesbrough, Coulby Newham, and Yarm were needed to contain the fire.
Pensioner robbed in Grimsby
A pensioner was robbed in Grimsby, external over the weekend.
The 81-year-old had an envelope containing his passport, birth certificate and sentimental items stolen from him on Rendel Street at about 13:30 on Saturday.
The suspect is described as white, 6ft tall, with fair hair, and was wearing blue shorts, t-shirt and trainers.
Listen: Acid attack pony now 'pain-free'
Vets treating an eight-month-old pony brought to Yorkshire for treatment, after being the victim of a suspected acid attack, say she "now appears to be free of pain."
Cinders has been receiving treatment at the Rainbow Equine Hospital in Malton, North Yorkshire.
David Rendle is part of the team caring for her and says "most of the problem areas have now been pretty much resolved" though she still has problems around her muzzle:
National recognition Hull hospital team
This is the Frailty Intervention Team (FIT) in Hull and they've been recognised as one of the best in the country.
It is their job to reduce unnecessary hospital admissions and it seems to be working.
More than two-thirds of people aged over 80 were being admitted to hospital before Hull and East Yorkshire Hospitals NHS Trust introduced FIT last year.
Now this team of specialists in elderly medicine work alongside staff in the Emergency Department at Hull Royal Infirmary seven days a week to help 70% of patients seen go home the same day.
The team will travel to London later this month after being named as a finalist in the 2018 Healthcare Transformation Awards for Innovation in the Care of Long Term Conditions.
Funding approved for film and TV studios in Doncaster
Grant funding for new film and television studios at the former High Melton campus of Doncaster College has been agreed.
The decision was made at the first meeting of the Sheffield City Region Combined Authority chaired by the new Mayor Dan Jarvis.
Members agreed that 4.1m of Local Growth Fund cash should go towards the project headed up by 360 Degrees Media, external.
The scheme incorporates a film and TV studios, a visual effects production facility, a film and TV training academy and a hotel and events business.
It's projected to create around 220 new jobs and potentially thousands more in the supply chain.
Suspected chemical leak in Holbeach
Five fire engines have been called to a manufacturing plant at Holbeach Hurn after a possible chemical leak.
Lincolnshire Fire and Rescue say police and ambulance are also at the scene on Marsh Lane.
Four members of staff at the plant have been assisted by fire crews, although it's not known if there are any serious injuries.
Pedestrian injured after lorry collision in Grantham
A woman's been seriously hurt in a collision with a lorry in Grantham.
The police say it happened on High Street just before 12:00.
The woman has been taken for treatment at QMC in Nottingham.
High Street is closed in both directions causing serious disruption to traffic in the town centre.
Listen: 'Smell the death' - Yorkshire asylum seeker
There are fears rough sleeper numbers could rise in Scarborough if 50 asylum seekers are allowed to live in the town.
The government wants the town to become an asylum seeker dispersal area.
But concerns have been raised in a report to be debated by the borough council's cabinet tomorrow, external.
The government can force the council to accept asylum seekers.
Sleman Shwaish, who now lives in Huddersfield, came to the UK to escape Syria in 2012.
He says it's a far cry from the sound of bombs dropping in Syria:
Two burglaries at Cleethorpes pub
Officers are looking for three men in connection with two burglaries, external which happened on the same night at a pub in Cleethorpes.
Both break-ins happened at Willy's pub on High Cliff Road between 04:30 and 06:00 on Monday 28 April.
In the first instance two men allegedly got in by smashing a glass door.
They broke a fruit machine open before stealing cash and leaving.
Around an hour later another man got in through the smashed door and allegedly stole two bottles of spirits from behind the bar.
Police are appealing for information.
Birds of a Feather star helps shop worker get to Edinburgh Fringe
A former supermarket manager from Doncaster is taking his play to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, external this summer.
Thomas Byatt, 25, has based the work, Bagged, on his experiences as a store manager in South Yorkshire.
Janet Marsh, one of his cast members, is his old drama teacher and runs the Pauline Quirke Academy in Doncaster.
She heard the Birds of a Feather star was willing to help people get the chance to perform in Edinburgh so she sent the script to her:
Six crews tackle bungalow blaze
Fire crews are removing roof tiles and damping down after a fire spread through four terraced bungalows in Stokesley in North Yorkshire.
Police say all the properties had to be evacuated and are asking people to avoid the area while emergency services work at the scene.
Firefighters say the blaze originally started in a back garden and then spread into roof space.
The cause is not yet known.
Two crews from Northallerton and engines from Stokesley, Middlesbrough, Coulby Newham, and Yarm were needed to contain the fire.
Pier support for Withernsea
A group wanting to build a new pier at Withernsea has received encouragement from the council that runs the only surviving pier in Yorkshire.
Managers of Saltburn Pier near Middlesbrough, where more than 500,000 people visit each year, says seaside piers can be a huge draw for tourists and are worth having.
Carl Quartermain, the Cabinet member for tourism at Redcar and Cleveland Council, admits Saltburn almost got rid of its pier in the 1970s.
Quote Message
The council at the time wrote to the secretary of state requesting that it was demolished. The secretary of state recognised that a lot of the pier was actually okay and saved the pier back in 1975."
Carl Quartermain, Redcar and Cleveland Council
The mystery of the shrouded tree
This tree looks as if its covered in frost but the picture was actually taken over the weekend when the sun was shining.
It's actually shrouded in spectacular cobweb-like nests.
PC Rich Sutcliffe snapped it along the banks of the River Wharfe, near Kilnsey, in North Yorkshire.
He says: "I've seen some mysterious sights at work but this took me by surprise.
"The whole tree was moving with caterpillars.
A bit of quick research into the phenomenon suggests it's caused by an infestation of either bird cherry ermine moth caterpillars or hawk moth caterpillars.
Listen: 'Needed to be recorded' - Grenfell documentary maker
A film about the Grenfell Tower tragedy has its world premiere tonight - it will be shown at Sheffield's Doc Fest, external and also on BBC1 at the same time.
This documentary brings together multiple stories from the tower block fire.
It was made over the course of one year, with filming starting on the day after the fire.
Ben Anthony, the film's director, said he felt the tragedy had to be documented:
